properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: African Canadian Youth  Justice Program offers culturally appropriate services, programs and referrals as community-based solutions for high-risk African Canadian youth involved in the Youth Criminal Justice System between the ages of 12 and 17 years.   Youth Outreach Worker Program supports marginalized and at-risk youth and their families to better navigate and connect with services and pro-social opportunities in their communities to improve youth outcomes.  Youth-In-Transition Worker provides support to youth between the age of 16 to 24 years living in the Durham, Toronto, and Peel Regions in their successful transition out of the Child Welfare system into adulthood.  The Employment Skills Job Readiness Program (ESJR) is geared towards providing training and skills development to African Canadian men who have multiple barriers in securing employment to enable them gain access to long term employment/apprenticeship opportunities within the skilled trades industry.  Knowledge Of Self provides cultural (Rites of Passage), Anti-Violence/Anti-Gang (Colour Coded), Anti-Drug (The Right Fix) and Anger Management (Life Lessons) group programming support to youth in the GTA.  These programming modules are designed to counteract the risk factors that lead to criminogenic and anti-social behaviours among African Canadian youth and provide linkages within the community that will build support systems, thus increasing the youthâ€™s protective factor.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Afrocentric approach, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, Strength-Based Therapy, etc.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: *Decrease recidivism. *Support youth's successful reintegration back to their communities after incarceration. *Support youth's successful transition from the Children's Aid Society to adulthood. * Support youth's access to community resources and services that will support successful outcomes. *Link at-risk youth to various Trades.
properties.Outcomes1: 15 - Ontario youth respect and are respected by the law and justice system
properties.Outcomes2: 20 - Ontario youth know about and easily navigate resources in their communities
properties.Outcomes3: 10 - Ontario youth have opportunities for meaningful employment opportunities
properties.Program_Funder: Ministry of Children and Youth Services (MCYS), Youth Justice Division, MCYS, Child Welfare,  MCYS Mental Health and Ministry of Economic Development, Trade and Employment.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: This is a Ministry of Community Safety and Correctional Services 'Promising Practice'.   The Aspire program is aimed at improving targeted at-risk communities and neighbourhoods in the City of Mississauga.  Recent literature has emphasized the role of education as an important determinant of crime, and given the prominent role of education in an individualâ€™s life, educational experience has both significant direct and indirect effects on criminality.  In modern societies, an individualâ€™s life trajectory â€“ including an individualâ€™s involvement in criminal activity â€“ is increasingly determined by his or her educational experiences.  In the early 1990â€™s, criminologists John Laub and Robert Sampson conducted research that demonstrated that school attitudes and performance (as measured by grades) affect delinquency rates.  High grade point averages and positive student attitudes toward school have been shown to reduce the likelihood of adolescent criminal behaviour.  To demonstrate, according to the U.S Department of Justice, only about 28% of incarcerated individuals in state and federal prisons have successfully graduated from high school. It is important to note that education is not merely a process that involves teaching the academics. It also includes teaching children social skills which help students feel more competent at school, at home, and in the community. Developing social skills at school is as significant as the academic domain. Learning how to get along with others, developing friendships, and establishing a positive out-look on life are critical. Students who are without social skills development experience rejection from classmates and learn to avoid social situations. Feelings of hurt and disappointment are the outcome and affect the child's ability to feel positive about school, peers and life in general.   The Roots of Youth Violence Report says that serious problems are being encountered in neighbourhoods trapped in a downward cycle of disadvantage where there are challenges to provide positive role-modeling to the children and youth.  Where poverty is an issue, this is a significant risk factor for involvement in criminal activity. While research concerning the relationship between poverty and crime does not show that poverty causes crime, Canadians living in poverty are over-represented in the offender population. The socio-economic difficulties faced by those living in poverty may increase the likelihood that an individual will become involved in criminal activity.  We firmly believe that providing these children and youth with a positive role model will make a difference in these communities.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: place-based, community operated crime prevention program rooted in education (tutoring) and crime prevention through social development

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: We are attempting to assist youth with long-term career planning, soft skills, life skills, pre-employment, and basic needs. Many of the youth we are serving cannot be served properly in the timeframe outlined within program guidelines. Most youth we see are on OW or have no income, little family support, lack of education (lack of OSSD), and lack the following: transportation, mental health supports, reasonable goals, references, positive view of employment, child care, housing. Many employers are not as willing to take on these youth as they lack skills, have no transportation, have criminal records, and have a poor perception of the workplace.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: We are delivering a 60 hour, pre-employment program, followed by placement with employers. We are also offering summer employment, which requires 20 hours of pre-employment training, followed by job placement.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Created in 1975, The War Amps Child Amputee (CHAMP) Program is built on the Winnerâ€™s Circle philosophy, which encourages child amputees (Champs) to accept their amputations and develop a positive approach to challenges.  CHAMP offers comprehensive services to Canadian child amputees and their families, such as:  Financial assistance for artificial limbs and recreational devices Regional CHAMP seminars, which provide a forum for young amputees and their parents to share information and advice and see new developments in artificial limbs Peer counselling and emotional support through programs like Matching Mothers CHAMP is open to Canadian children under 18 who are born missing a limb or limbs or have lost a limb due to an accident or medical causes.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Financial assistance for artificial limbs, peer support and regional seminars
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Provide financial assistance to amputees for their artificial limbs so that they can live a full and active life. properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Connect the Sector (CTS)  is a community of younger professionals, connecting across generations, with the common goals of learning from each other. We collaborate to shape the future of the nonprofit sector.   Since 2012, CTS has hosted dozens of public panels, discussions, working sessions, workshops, and networking events. We're drawing hundreds of nonprofit professionals together. We have an established steering committee, and operate formally as an incubated project of the Ontario Nonprofit Network (ONN). This year, we are focused on intergenerational policy dialogue.     CTS is a space where the many voices in our sector â€“ volunteers, employees at all stages and levels, activists, social entrepreneurs, civil servants, policy wonks and sector champions â€“ all collaborate for systems change through thoughtful knowledge exchange.Younger and older non-profit professionals come together to share ideas, understand each other, and together are shaping the future of the non-profit sector.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Fellowship; integration with working groups on nonprofit policy issues, etc.
properties.Outcomes1: 20 - Ontario youth know about and easily navigate resources in their communities
properties.Program_Funder: We are an incubated project of the Ontario Nonprofit Network. We get some administrative and in-kind support from them, and we have received some small grants.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: We work with a wide range of  issues that include: challenging peer and/or family relationships, school performance and/or attendance concerns, abuse, mental health challenges, substance misuse, sexual orientation/health issues, bullying, suicidal thoughts, gang-affiliation, social, emotional, and/or behavioural challenges. Services occur at our main office and in two Toronto high schools: Northern Secondary and City Adult Learning Centre.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Counsellors engage with each youth in a way that suits their particular needs and enhances their own understanding of their challenges. Interventions that are used include: cognitive behavioural therapy, trauma informed CBT, motivational interviewing and Dialectical Behaviour Therapy.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Counsellors engage with each youth in a way that suits their particular needs and enhances their own understanding of their challenges. The goal is to assist youth in developing skills and coping strategies that will enable them to function effectively at home, in school and in the community.  With the youth's consent whenever possible parents or guardians are engaged in treatment. Clinicians work in partnership with clients to improve coping strategies by teaching communication skills, exploring feelings and emotions, examining life narratives utilizing solution-focused language to support resilience and successful outcomes.

DANCE ROCK -  This is a safe venue for people of all alternate abilities to come and create connections, get their bodies moving and express the joy they have for life. This is held once per month at two locations: Bayview and Eglinton Yonge and Windermere This event is run by parents, Board members and volunteers. 2016 is our 10th year for Dance Rock and we get 120 - 150 people in attendance at our dances.  PAL 19+ - Adults with Down Syndrome meet once per month in a restaurant or theme venue to create relationships and have a fun night out together. Each outing will be organized, led and fully supervised by the DSAT PAL 19+ team consisting of Board members and volunteers.   PAL 13/19 -  Teens with Down syndrome meet new friends, gain independence and develop life skills through fun, social outings. Each outing is organized, led and fully supervised by the DSAT PAL 1319 team consisting of parents, professionals and volunteers. Such outings will include, but not limited to movies, bowling, dinner, etc. and will occur once a month.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: DeMolay is a youth leadership organization building young men of character and dedicated to making young men better people and leaders. Providing a program based on timeless principles and practical experience, DeMolay strives to not only create the extraordinary leader, but a leader of character. DeMolays hold themselves to a higher moral standard, striving to constantly improve and be better each and every day.  DeMolay is a youth-led, adult-advised organization in which young men learn to plan, organize, and facilitate their own programs. DeMolays take part in a wide-range of activities, from athletic competitions, to public speaking tournaments, to community service events. All activities are guided by the interests of the local chapter. If you can dream it, you can do it in DeMolay.  DeMolay provides endless fun and friendships that last a lifetime, even with such a serious mission. When a young man joins DeMolay, he instantly gains over four million brothers across the globe. No youth organization provides such life-changing experiences like DeMolay.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Personal Development: Through the practice of our core values, skills, and personal relationships we encourage positive behavior, good health, and achievement.  In this youth-led organization we encourage the young men to plan and participate in activities such as teambuilding events, athletic competitions, community service, social activities, and leadership workshops.  These events challenge each and every member to better themselves as individuals and as a group.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Personal Development Leadership Community Service
properties.Outcomes1: 11 - Ontario youth have the skills and resources needed to develop a successful career or business
properties.Outcomes2: 18 - Ontario youth leverage their assets to address social issues

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Design Exchange is Canada's only museum dedicated to  is committed to making design education accessible for all. Our education programs harness the experience and expertise of DXâ€™s design programs and provide high quality design education directly to children and youth onsite at the museum, in the schools, community and neighbourhood centres .
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Design-based workshops and activities
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: DX aims to build strong partnerships with the goal to eliminate barriers to participation such as transportation, the cost of admission, or any feelings of exclusivity museums can sometime inspire. Overcoming barriers to participation and addressing vulnerability factors means more children and youth can access the life-long benefits of design education. Through outreach programs, children and youth who may not otherwise have access receive the opportunity to explore design as hands-on creators, audiences and performers. We provide the tools to connect design learning to life experience, and especially to create sustained engagement with communities across Toronto.

properties.Name_Program: Diverse Reintegration Youth Program (DRYP), Victim Offender Reconciliation Program (VORP), Conflict Anger Learning Communication Mediation Program (CALM),  Peer Mediation-Circles,
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: As a solution, DRYP offers services that provide resources, acts as a liaison and demonstrates the race and culturally related expertise needed to ensure that youth and their family receive suitable communication, education and referral services. Mentorship, leadership and volunteerism are also significant elements of our service delivery where youth explore their full potential while maintaining positive and constructive relationships with their community. We also provide informal and formal programming and training opportunities that supports the further development of life skills for participating youth.  CALM provides youth with the opportunity to develop skills (primarily conflict management skills) so they can improve relationships with peers, parents and those in authority. Youth will have a positive environment to explore their personal conflict and anger styles. The participants will have the opportunity to strengthen their ability to address issues surrounding conflict in a productive manner that supports conflict resolution. This will reduce and minimize the escalation of violence within our communities.   VORP- is a community-based program which offers the courts and community a different way of dealing with the aftermath of crime. VORP provides an opportunity for a victim and offender to meet face-to-face in order to find a mutually satisfying solution to the offence and its effects. Participants are given a chance to ask questions about the offence, to express their feelings and to negotiate an agreement for repayment of losses when these occur. Participation is voluntary and mediation meetings are arranged and facilitated by trained volunteer mediators.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: DRYP assists with youth independence after involvement with the law. These programs include anger management training, WHMIS, Understanding and Managing Aggressive Behaviour (UMAB for youth and volunteers). Also budgeting, cooking/nutrition, housing, medical needs, education, job preparation skills, home maintenance, general health, etc. CALM is embedded in the workshop series will be the following.  Workshop 1 â€“ Conflict  Workshop 2 â€“ Anger  Workshop 3 â€“ Learning communication  Workshop 4 â€“ Mediation. VORP- Participants are responded to as persons and treated with fairness. Once they meet in a face-to-face meeting, the stereotyped images of â€œvictimâ€ and â€œoffenderâ€ begin to fade.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: DRYP-Our objective is to provide a community-based referral option that will develop, implement and supervise specific activities relevant to holding young people accountable for reparation of harm done and provide opportunities for the young person to become contributing members of the community. CALM-The skills gained in the workshops are useful for all relationships and each participant will receive a certificate upon completion of all four workshops. VORP-Victims, Offenders and Communities benefit because resolution and restitution are more productive and economical than some other sentencing alternatives. Through the victimâ€™s and the volunteerâ€™s involvement, the community is represented in the justice process and in helping to make offenders more productive members of their communities.
properties.Outcomes1: 20 - Ontario youth know about and easily navigate resources in their communities

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Our Youth Support Program provides bereaved youth with the opportunity to meet other same aged peers who have also experienced the death of an immediate family member. Through weekly groups, youth access free clinical support from Dr. Jay grief counsellors while exploring healthy ways of supporting themselves through storytelling, art, music and physical expression. WE have created this program to meet the diverse needs of Toronto's youth affected by homicide, suicide, accidental and medically related deaths. We support youth through a wide range of issues connected to their grief including academic challenges, mental health, substance use, physical health needs, financial and housing struggles.   We provide our youth with the opportunity to participate in our Leader in Training (LIT) program, whereby they undergo grief-specific training in leadership, communication and team-building. They receive strong mentorship from other bereaved adults and leaders amongst our communities. Our LITs participate at our annual grief and bereavement camp, Camp Erin Toronto.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Our peer support model offers an integrated approach, allowing youth to explore their grief through a range of practices including narrative, expressive-arts, music,

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: As per my 15 years of community experience, most of the Youth are focused just about their career, entertainment, education etc., They are not bothered about voting or the future of this country ! I witness lack of sensitivity not just to their culture/religion/language, but to their own community at large. Lack of networking, community involvement, responsibility to save the environment, communication skill etc., prevents them from growing ! They are just bothered about their 40 hours of community hours to get in to University ! I strive hard along with many parent volunteers to engage the youth of various communities to take part in over 40 Durham based community events every year, to enable them to get the taste of being a good human and not just a Grade student.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Girlfriends is an after school program for all girls in grades 7 & 8 and is run by women, for young women. It is hands on and active in nature, with volunteer mentors and guest female professionals from the community providing positive leadership and serving as role models for the participants. It is our hope to help develop the self esteem of young woman, to inspire and to empower them. We want to encourage them to have choice and most importantly to be confident in the choices they make. The â€œGIRLFRIENDSâ€ program will provide them with a space to be true to who they are, to learn, to laugh and to understand other points of view. Mostly we expect these young woman to walk away standing a little taller and feeling self assured. During Girlfriends, participants are given the tools needed to help improve their nutrition, physical fitness, self-esteem, and relationships. This comes in the form of healthy snacks and nutrition tips, accessible fitness activities, as well as respectful and supportive discussions. Our goal is to not only improve the girls' health in the short term, but throughout their lives.  We believe that participants' awareness and attitudes toward healthy living and environmental responsibility will evolve over the course of the program, giving them the tools needed for continued personal change.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: To be kind to one another
properties.Outcomes1: 6 - Ontario form and maintain healthy close relationships
properties.Program_Funder: Individual Schools, various Ministry's, private donors.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Our vision at Girls Inc. is empowered girls living in an equitable society.  We offer a variety of programs both in schools and in our community that focus on helping girls reach their full potential.   We use our signature, research-based curriculum which focuses on a variety of themes such as leadership & community action, media literacy, economic literacy, Operation SMART (STEM theme), Project Bold (self-defense and anti-bullying theme), Literacy, and more to reach girls where they are and help them to succeed. properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: This is a weekend camp experience for Grade 8 girls that focuses on education through specific learning and active engagement strategies designed to provide information and critical review of issues facing girls ...self confidence, self esteem, media pressures, bullying, body image, etc. The camp is a collaborative project between three community agencies. It is facilitated by agency staff and youth/young women volunteers, many who are camp alumni. Girls are prepared to enter high school and are connected with specific facilitators during the weekend that they can later connect with in Grade 9.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: As described above, the weekend utilizes several activities to engage the girls in learning new information and developing some analysis and understanding of issues facing girls. Activities such as a high ropes course, media education, self defense, and small group discussions provide the opportunities for girls to connect with each other in a fun, learning environment.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Girls Power Camp is a weekend camping experience held each year for Grade 8 girls in Haldimand-Norfolk.  The goals of the camp are:  â€¢	To raise awareness if girls and young women about issues such as body image, peer pressure, healthy relationships, female bullying and personal safety; â€¢	To develop critical thinking skills among young women so they can make informed decisions; â€¢	To inform girls and young women of support services available to them in their community, and how to access them; â€¢	To create a seamless transition for girl students entering Grade 9; and â€¢	To build self-esteem and confidence among participants.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The Integra Program provides mental health intervention exclusively to children and youth with Learning Disabilities and Mental Health issues (LDMH).  Often youth have co-occurring diagnoses including Autism Spectrum Disorders and ADHD.  We have a large population of youth who participate in individual and family therapy.  The majority of our youth attend our innovative group therapy programs, including Integra Mindfulness Martial Arts, Integra Social Competence Group Program, and Towhee. Older youth take on roles as mentors and youth leaders in the Integra MMA and Towhee programs.  Treatment outcomes include: improved emotion regulation; reduced anxiety; improved self-esteem; improved social competence; skills in leadership;  and self-advocacy.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Innovative evidence-informed interventions that have been developed and evaluated by Integra staff include: Integra Mindfulness Martial Arts (CBT, mindfulness, DBT informed); Integra Social Competence Group Program (social learning theory); Towhee (CPS, DBT informed).  We tailor evidence based interventions including CBT, and also solution focused, collaborative problem solving, DBT, mindfulness, and systemic family therapy
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Integra MMA:  over 10 years of research in partnership with universities (Toronto, Ryerson, Trent, McMaster) indicates positive changes in self regulation, attention, cognitive flexibility, and reduced anxiety.   Towhee:  research outcomes indicate reduced anxiety, improved self-concept; improved social competence Integra Social Competence Group Program: research outcomes indicate increased social risk taking, social engagement.  we are currently evaluating outcomes including chanaged social skills and social awareness.
properties.Outcomes1: 2 - Ontario youth feel mentally healthy
properties.Outcomes2: 13 - Ontario youth experience social inclusion and value diversity
properties.Program_Funder: MCYS (plus supplementary user fees for Towhee and Integra Mindfulness Martial Arts programs, which are supported by donations

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Justice for Children and Youth strives to protect and advance the legal rights and dignity of children and youth in Canada. Voice and empowerment are important tenets of the mission. By providing children and youth with the tools and context which allows them to speak for themselves as individual rights holders in our society is the most effective way to preserve their rights. Justice for Children and Youth provides select legal representation to low-income children and youth in Toronto and vicinity. We are a non-profit legal aid clinic that specializes in protecting the rights of those facing conflicts with the legal system, education, social service or mental health systems. We give summary legal advice, information and assistance to young people, parents (in education matters), professionals and community groups across Ontario.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Kids Help Phone provides 24/7, anonymous, professional counselling in English and French to young people ages 5-20 through phone and Live Chat.  Young people in Canada reach out to us over 1.2 million times each year through out various service channels, including our four award winning youth websites.  Our web content and counselling services help young people through any issue or challenge they are facing including diagnosed and diagnosable mental health challenges, gender identity, substance abuse, bullying, suicide, violence and family and peer relationships.   As a charity with more than 25 years experience helping kids face the challenges of growing up, we help young people develop resiliency, build confidence and emotional strengths, and increase coping and decision-making skills.  In addition, Kids Help Phone maintains the largest database of services for youth in the province with nearly 15,000 resources available.  Finally, Kids Help Phone, along with three partner agencies, runs the Good2Talk helpline which provides professional counselling to post-secondary students in Ontario.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Solution focused Brief therapy, Narrative therapy and crisis intervention
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Kids Help Phone has a logic model with the outcomes we expect young people will experience as a result of our counselling.  We anticipate that in the short term, service users will experience positive changes in their feelings and attitudes (i.e. a reduction in distress and increase in confidence and hope) followed by changes in awareness and knowledge (i.e. increase in awareness of personal strengths and resources and awareness of choices and options).  Because we understand change to be a process, we know that developing skills and changes in behaviours are more likely intermediate and log-term outcomes as a result of multiple counselling sessions.  O

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: LIFE Toronto serves young people who have a physical disability and are making the transition into adulthood. The program provides participants with a learning environment to expand their social and professional skills while practicing the daily responsibilities of adulthood. LIFE Torontoâ€™s goal is to bridge the gap between child and adult services by providing participants with new skills and resources. LIFE Toronto is a combination of Life Skills Workshops, Transit Training, weekly Social & Recreational Outings, and Conductive Education.   In conjunction with our sponsors United Way and TD, March of Dimes Canada is offering a ten week LIFE program in Toronto, Ontario. The program is offered four times per year.   Opportunities for real-life application in the community will be encountered during the Social & Recreational Outings. These Outings include trips to Toronto Island, a day bowling, visiting parks, nature hikes, swimming, going to lunch and a movie, participating in organized sports at Variety Village and many others.   Along with the fun and adventure, you will experience some challenges. Indeed, the very purpose of the program is to help you find untapped resources within yourself and within your group, to help you discover that you are more capable than you know. This is one of the huge benefits of this disability management program for young adults. The complimentary components of the program will foster independence within the individual.  Each applicant must:  Have a physical disability Be able to direct his or her own care Be between the ages of 19-30
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Holistic, Rec-based
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Increase independence   This looks different for each participant and could included:  -increased mobility -increased ability to direct care  -increased civic participation and advocacy -increased participation in adaptive sport and Rec to maintain a healthy and active lifestyle -improved social skills -improved skills necessary for daily living activities and for future planning

properties.Name_Program: Making Play Possible as well as the core services as outlined by MCYS for mental health treatment of children and youth
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Children's Mental Health of Leeds and Grenville offers the full continuum of  core services as outlined by the Ministry of Child and Youth Services. They provide programs and services in targeted prevention, brief services, counselling and therapy, family skill building and support, specialized consultation and assessment, crisis support services and intensive treatment services. They also provide tele-mental health services when needed for treatment planning. Services start with a brief telephone intake where a single session consultation is scheduled in approximately 7-10 days of making a referral. Clients experiencing crisis will receive same day service. There is also a walk-in service in our Brockville office from 11a.m.-7p.m. on Wednesdays (last appointment 5:30pm). The agency provides additional walk-in services at all offices during the summer. Assistance with recreational activities though our Making Play Possible program can also accessed by calling the office. Please call or visit our website for additional information.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: if a child, youth or family requires mental health services in Leeds and Grenville they can recieve servcies from our agency as we are the only agency located in Leeds and Grenville offering MCYS funded mental health services.

properties.Program_Funder: Making Play Possible is partially funded by MCYS but all of the dollars that support recreational opportunities come from community fundriasing. Mental health services are funded through MCYS.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: CACD's Mental Health Awareness program will provide accessible preventive support systems for children and youth struggling with mental health challenges including depression, self-harm, low self-esteem, antisocial behaviour, anxiety, eating disorders and poor coping skills.  Our audience is high risk youth ages 13 to 18 years-old attending secondary school within the Mississauga community, specifically targeting those exhibiting characteristics of potential mental health issues with open, frank and respectful discussion about mental illness. Through this program, children and youth will learn how to access personal, professional, and/or community support and have the option to attend safe, confidential and non-judgmental workshops held throughout the school year (September-June). The workshops will be led by a qualified mental health facilitator selected by our mental health providers (Canada Mental Health Center and Nexus, affiliate of the Peel Children's Centre), along with interns who are trained and educated in the "40 developmental asset". In addition, our child and youth worker interns are knowledgeable about mental health, through their Sheridan College (Child and Youth Worker CYW) program .The facilitator will have previous experience working with youth aged 13 to 18 and have extensive knowledge of the following:  *Depression  *Anxiety Disorder  *Stress & Coping Skills  *Relationships and Support Systems  *Physical, Emotional and Psychological Abuse  *Mental Health Stigma  *Self-Harm & Suicide  *Behavioral Disorders/Bullying  *Aggressive and antisocial behaviour  *Eating Disorder
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: The program will be initiated with the choosing of secondary schools within the Peel District School Board and the Dufferin Peel Catholic District School Board. As mentioned above, a qualified health facilitator will be hired through our collaboration with Nexus Youth Services and its partner Peel Children's Centre and our youth workers trained in the 40 Developmental Assets established to run the programs at Mississauga Valley Community Center, a central location. Youth will be referred to the project through school personnel, this includes teachers, guidance counselors, Peel Police service, court divergence program and other youth focus organizations etc. Parents and guardians consent will be requested before youth can participate in the program. Once all the referrals for the term have been made, other youth can apply to enter the program and their applications will be access and accepted on needs basis. Incentives such as mental health awareness certificates and other professional documentation will be administered to those youth who complete the 12 week program
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: providing new resources for early intervention ( Client Satisfaction)

properties.Program_Funder: Currently we are Bell Canada, BMO, Statefarm and various foundations on board and excited to contribute to the inniciative.

properties.Name_Program: Mino Bimawdiziwin Children and Caregiver's Program
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Mino Bimawdiziwin means "A Good Way of Life" in the Anishinaabe (Ojibwe) language, it describes the concurrent program for Children, Youth, and Caregivers. It seeks to restore healthy and balanced relationships in Indigenous communities through cultural resurgence and traditional teachings.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Holistic culturally relevant and community based healing
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Provide the opportunity for Native Children and Youth to share their perspective and maintain a child and youth led program.  Provide the opportunity for Native Children, Youth, and their Caregivers to share about their experiences and learn about healthy relationships.   Provide the opportunity for Native families and communities to rebuild their cultural identity and have access to traditional ways of healing. properties.Name_Program: Nexus Youth Centre and Community Counselling Program
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Nexus Youth Services provides two primary programs: â€¢	The Community Counselling program offers individual, evidence-informed counselling rooted in youth engagement practices.  Catering to the unique needs of youth and young adults, this service builds on individual strengths to develop coping skills to enable a smooth transition into adulthood with minimal or no familial involvement.  Youth meet with the clinical staff at a mutually agreeable location, usually at the main office, Nexus Youth Centre (NYC), or another community location that meets the youthâ€™s needs. Entry to counselling is through a single session model called Step One to Success (SOS). A plan to achieve goals is centered on the youthâ€™s needs, wishes, capacity and preferences. Some of the recommended interventions may be seamlessly accessed through Nexus Youth Centreâ€™s formal programs (such as life-skills or social groups).  â€¢	Located in the Mississauga Central Library, Nexus Youth Centre (NYC), offers drop-in services, and formal programming through the utilization of youth engagement strategies.  At NYC, youth can meet peers in a safe, welcoming place; participate in a wide range of activities to improve their social skills; learn strategies to cope with the challenges of their daily lives; and improve their job and leadership skills. Through both informal individual counselling and formal programming including groups, youth have access to a range of services dealing with social competence, diversity, and skill development. Youth engagement strategies focus on youth developing leadership skills to engage them in meaningful opportunities through their involvement at NYC. As part of this approach, an active youth engagement working group assists in developing relevant programming, and participates in decision-making processes to further the exposure and services of NYS within the Peel community.  Collaborative partnerships with community agencies, committees and planning tables support and enhance clinical service for youth in Peel. Where possible, NYS provides support and leadership to other agencies and groups working to engage youth, sharing successes and lessons learned from our youth engagement efforts to date.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Youth engagement framework, positive youth development, motivational interviewing, CBT, DBT, Narrative Therapy
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Community Counselling outcomes: â€¢	actively engage youth in the treatment process developing their goals in collaboration with staff  â€¢	assist youth to increase their capacity to recognize and cope with challenges they may be experiencing; â€¢	support youth to improve their emotional functioning; â€¢	encourages youth to develop helpful coping strategies as alternatives to self-harm and/or substance use; â€¢	supports youth in developing and maintaining positive relationships with peers and adults; and â€¢	works with youth to improve and sustain increased success in school and/or the community.  Outcomes of Nexus Youth Centre aim to increase the youthâ€™s: â€¢	engagement in activities that address their needs; â€¢	awareness of community resources; â€¢	knowledge and skills to cope with their daily lives; â€¢	decision-making, leadership and role-modelling skills; â€¢	capacity and skills to obtain and sustain employment; and â€¢	ability to build positive social relationships with peers and adults in the community.

properties.Name_Program: Notre Dame House Community Resource Center
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The Community Resource Centre consists of a daily drop-in supports and youth programming, a hot meal program, and Section 23 Classroom. Through the Community Resource Center youth have access to care coordination which can consist of referrals to internal and external services There are four Mental Health Clinicians who will work with youth to provide assessment, treatment and mental health wellness coordination. Three clinicians specialize in working with minority populations; one with Early Intervention Youth, one with Aboriginal Youth and one with LGBTQ+ youth with concurrent disorders. Through the Mental Health Program, all youth at Notre Dame House also have access to adolescent psychiatrists, when indicated.  Skills for Life is a DBT/Mindfulness based program developed by the Mental Health team at Good Shepherd Youth Services. The curriculum teaches youth and their families positive Skills for managing and coping with thoughts, feelings and behaviors. All youth are able to participate in weekly programming that teaches and reinforces these Skills. All Youth Services staff are trained in the Skills for Life Program and can teach and provide coaching of the Skills with youth. Another service all youth are able to access a Housing Worker. Notre Dame House has three Housing Workers, each who works with a specific population to provide youth specialized support, depending on their individual needs. To address the continuum of homelessness, there is one worker who supports youth who have never been exposed to the shelter system. This Early Intervention Worker collaborates with youth and their families to divert the youth back to the family home, whenever it is safe. The Youth Homelessness Prevention worker works with youth who are currently in shelter or who may be experiencing precarious housing in the community, to find, obtain and maintain safe and adequate housing. The Intensive Community Case Manager works from a Housing First framework, to assist youth who have experienced chronic or episodic homelessness. The Intensive Community Case Managersâ€™ focus is to help youth find safe and adequate housing, connecting them with any and all supports they need to maintain this housing.  All youth are also able to receive confidential medical care through several on-site medical clinics. A Doctor, a Nurse and a Public Health Sexual Health Nurse will meet with youth for a variety of reasons. Youth may receive referrals, ongoing treatment, medication, medical testing and harm reduction education through these clinics. Through these medical clinics and a partnership with the Shelter Health Networkâ€™s Hepatitis C team youth are able to receive prompt and cohesive services to prevent and treat blood borne illnesses.     Another service is on-site Addictions Counselling (Alternatives for Youth). AY offers ongoing counselling, referrals to treatment centers and harm reduction education, as well as supports youth with concurrent disorders. There is a weekly Legal Clinic where youth can receive confidential legal advice on a variety of matters including criminal law, family law, and housing and mental health law. Another clinic that runs during the drop-in hours of CRC is the Employment Preparation Program. This program assists youth with employment searching, resume building and employment readiness.    Every youth is invited to participate in programming. All programming is created based on one of our principals of programming: 1) Life Skills (including how to budget, grocery shop and prepare a meal, how to go to a Laundromat to complete laundry, etc.), 2) Skills for Life (coping with thoughts, feelings and behaviour), 3) Recreation (involving youth in activities to help build confidence and mastery) and 4) Community Engagement. The CRC also provides youth with access to clothing donations, housing donations and a hot meal program two times daily. All of these initiatives help to relieve some of the financial burden felt by a young person living independently, which is crucial for them to maintain housing. Notre Dame House is often the first step for youth in their journey to continuing education. Many referrals for the Notre Dame House School come from the CRC.  The Notre Dame House School is a Section 23 Classroom, assisting street involved and homeless youth in re-engaging in the education sector through alternative learning. The Notre Dame House School provides many opportunities to assist youth in obtaining their high school diploma including cooperative education opportunities, independent booklet study and artistic opportunities. There is a Post-Secondary Liaison who attends the school bi-weekly to discuss with youth their options for post-secondary education, and assist them in the application process. Any youth who accesses the CRC or lives in the shelter has the ability to meet with this worker as well. At Notre Dame House youth are supported in connecting with cultural and spiritual services that can help them re-establish connections with their own culture and/or spirituality.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The Notre Dame House Shelter is a 21 bed emergency shelter for street involved and homeless youth in Hamilton, Ontario. As the only youth shelter in Hamilton, Notre Dame House is often the only safe space for youth to access in the city. Without the shelter, many youth between the ages of 16 and 18 would have nowhere to go. Providing youth with a safe, accepting and welcome environment to land has many positive impacts on the youth themselves, as well as the local community. The Notre Dame House shelter helps decrease the number of youth living in invisible homelessness, and works to decrease the volume of youth who have to become involved in high-risk activities such as transactional sex work, gang involvement and drug dealing by supporting them in securing a place to live â€“ which in turn increases the chances that a youth who experiences homelessness will be able to be able to begin making steps towards positive life changes and lifting themselves of out poverty. The Notre Dame House Emergency shelter will assist a youth in meeting their immediate needs. Through a warm meal, a clean bed and a caring conversation, staff begin to build the foundation that will hold the youth up as they begin their journey out of homelessness. After immediate need is met and crisis is managed Notre Dame House will walk beside youth as they take the difficult steps towards adulthood.

properties.Name_Program: Notre Dame House Youth Substance Use Program
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: in partnership with Menâ€™s Withdrawal Management Centre and Womankind. The YSUP program is on site daily, to support youth who access hostel when under the influence to detox safely or be referred to emergency medical services when necessary. Providing youth with a safe place to go regardless of their level of sobriety reduces the risk of youth needing to engage in transactional sex to have somewhere to sleep or having to spend the night in unsafe situations. It also greatly reduces the number of youth who would need to utilize emergency or Hospital Services.  For example, last year there were 656 diversions from hospital and youth safely detoxed at Notre Dame YSUP program.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Our program directly addresses the specific needs of at-risk youth, ages 6 to 15, who are professionally referred due to mental health issues, learning challenges and other complex emotional, social, behavioural and/or cultural issues. We provide youth with a fully trained youth mentor, ages 16 to 29, who provides ongoing and consistent guidance, a positive role model and tailored, specialized support to help youth develop resiliency and overcome life's challenges. Mentors spend an average of 3 hours per week with their mentee for a minimum of 1 year (average duration of 5 years). The program is extremely comprehensive, including in-depth client needs assessments, volunteer assessments and matching and support processes that lead to a deep and life-changing impact for both the mentor and mentee. Mentees benefit from increased resiliency, confidence and a stronger connection to school, family and the community. Mentors benefit from increased confidence, job / career skills, a sense of accomplishment and a strong sense of civic engagement. The program is evidence-informed and proven to build resiliency in youth.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Our program uses a community-based, peer-to-peer (youth-to-youth) mentoring model.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Youth mentees, ages 6 to 15, benefit from: increased resiliency, confidence and academic performance, as well as improved relationships both at home and at school.  Volunteer youth mentors benefit from increased confidence, communications skills, job / career skills, a sense of accomplishment and a connection to community and civic engagement.  Reply to question below regarding our Evaluation Report: We completed our first ever full evaluation of 98 youth within one-to-one program in October of 2015. This was done through our existing Resiliency Evaluation Framework. However, our evaluation report is not yet complete. We would like to share the report with you with it's ready.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The death of a parent or sibling is difficult at any age.  For a child, it is difficult and isolating.   Our peer bereavement support groups help children, teens and their families recover and readjust after a death in the family.  At Lighthouse our families find and create a community of understanding, stability and support during this difficult time.  Our groups are ongoing and open-ended allowing each family member to participate in his or her own way.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Open-ended peer bereavement support groups are facilitated by professional staff and trained volunteers.  In our groups, children and teens explore their feelings in experiences in an environment of acceptance, compassion and non-judgement through talk circles, group activities, visual and dramatic arts, and play.  We do not provide counseling or therapy but facilitate an environment of self help that empowers the children learn coping skills while experiencing their own unique journeys in grief.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Decreased isolation Increased coping skills Decrease in intensity of grief feelings

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The March Youth Program, Power in Me, includes a series of workshops that focus on youth from a personal and individual perspective while in a group setting. Power In Me raises self-awareness in young people and educates them on the importance of empowering themselves on self-image (self-acceptance, self-confidence and self-esteem), while learning how to build leadership skills and learning the basic fundamentals of job seeking â€“ all facilitated in a creative and dynamic fashion. By focusing on three main components- Building Self-esteem and Leadership , Career Focus and Employment search, as well as, Social Media and Self-Image, we want to enable participants of the program to learn ways to empower themselves and become leaders of tomorrow in a well rounded way.

Participants will learn the fundamentals of job searching and no career is unachievable  ?	Participants will gain leadership skills, an understanding of community involvement and their roles in personal growth ?	Participants will understand the social mediaâ€™s negative influence on self-esteem and once self, and learn to navigate the platform in a positive manner for self and others ?	Participants will learn to step outside of their comfort zone and try new things

properties.Name_Program: Programming is developed by 4-H Ontario and we deliver the programming to youth in Huron County. Clubs are either agricultural or lifeskill based.
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: 4-H is a grass roots organization of leaders building leaders. At 4-H, we believe it is important to look at the big picture; youth need to see beyond themselves and focus on how their actions affect personal relationships, their community, the environment and society as a whole. This is reflected in the 4-H Pledge, which is said at the beginning of every 4-H meeting or event. The 4-H Pledge encourages a balanced lifestyle (intellectual, emotional, physical, spiritual), and reminds participants to always aim to be a good friend, mentor, community member and citizen. Dedicated Volunteers work with Members to develop leadership and life skills that equip them with tools to reach their full potential and become conscious and contributing citizens.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: 4-H's motto is 'Learn to do by doing'.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: At 4-H, we believe it is important to look at the big picture; youth need to see beyond themselves and focus on how their actions affect personal relationships, their community, the environment and society as a whole.

properties.Name_Program: Royal Canadian Sea Cadet Corps Warspite
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The mission of the Cadet Program is to contribute to the development and preparation of youth for the transition to adulthood, enabling them to meet the challenges of modern society, through a dynamic, community-based program. The vision of the Cadet Program is a relevant, credible and proactive youth development organization, offering the program of choice for Canadaâ€™s youth, preparing them to become the leaders of tomorrow through a set of fun, challenging, well-organized and safe activities. We further commit to attain this vision by living shared Canadian and military values, paying particular attention to: - Loyalty, the expression of our collective dedication to the ideals of the Cadet Movement to all its members; - Professionalism, the accomplishment of all tasks with pride and diligence; - Mutual Respect, the treatment of others with dignity and equality; and - Integrity, the courage and commitment to exemplify trust, sincerity and honesty.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Sea Cadets is available to any young man or woman between the ages of 12 to 18 years of age.  Using a militaristic naval model we assist youth to become good citizens and leaders of Canada and thsir local communities.  There are some restrictions for disabled and youth willmental issues.  We will try to adjust the program for them based upon their ability to communicate and how good their motor functions are.
properties.Outcomes1: 21 - Undefined
properties.Program_Funder: The program is 100% funded by the Department of National Defense and the Navy League of Canada through the local Kitchener-Waterloo Branch of volunteers.  There is no financial responsibility from the cadets or their parents required for membership or any expenses.  They are expected to assist occasionally with fundraising.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The Canadian Centre for Gender and Sexual Diversity (CCGSD) intersectionally promotes diversity in gender identity, gender expression, and romantic and/or sexual orientation in all its forms on a national level through services in the areas of education, health, and advocacy. Our resources and programming can be used to uplift gender and sexual minorities, as well as give the tools to wider populations in building allyship.  As a leader in anti-discrimination work, CCGSD runs programming all over Canada and the United States. Because of our hundreds of volunteers, we are able to reach over 250,000 people annually. We are also a proud leader in the International Day of Pink (DayOfPink.org), engaging millions of people in wearing pink and to run programs that stand up to bullying. We encourage you to find out more about CCGSD & the International Day of Pink, and get involved in making your community a safer and more diverse place.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: SESSIONS is designed to provide youth with drug neutral, balanced information about drugs, to build health literacy, critical thinking, decision making skills and youth resiliency and to assist youth in developing trusting relationships with adults.  Additional objectives of the program are for youth to understand how and where to find factual information; the analytical skills to evaluate information; the skills to assess harm and benefit; an understanding of the social and environmental influences of drug use; strategies to attain and maintain physical emotional and social well being; and to identify supportive people and resources in their community.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Facilitators use music, art, literature, media and games to create a safe, drug-neutral space to engage youth as they develop health literacy skills with the goal of supporting them to make informed choices about their own health and wellness.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: A core outcome the program hopes to impact is ensuring that if youth are going to use a substance that they make an informed choice that includes factors related to their own health and well being and develop the skills they will use as an adult in making these decisions.  Numerous areas are measured in pre/post surveys.  The primary outcomes are related to: a  change in knowledge and skills related to drug use; beliefs about benefits and harms of drug use; the likelihood of future drug use; the way drugs are used and the value of obtaining accurate information when considering using a substance.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: SNAP Boys Youth Leadership Services (SNAP BYLS) was developed as a continued care service for SNAP graduates who could benefit from ongoing continued support and/or for those boys who continue to endure challenges especially as they enter the adolescent phase (aged 12 and older) and require further SNAP interventions to deal with a new set of challenges associated with adolescence and puberty. This program aims to support these â€˜SNAP graduatesâ€™ who, although demonstrating positive changes during their SNAP Boys intervention, may still remain at high risk of possible involvement in the criminal justice system, gang affiliation, early school dropout, and/or serious mental health issues. SNAP Boys Youth Leadership Services engages approximately 30 at-risk youth every year, with stimulating leadership programming that complements a counselling and treatment approach based on their level of risk and need that continues to reinforce their SNAP learnings, the strategy and approach.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: SB-YLS is founded in SNAP (Stop Now And Plan), an internationally-recognized model for teaching behaviourally troubled children (ages 6-11), youth (ages 12 â€“ 18) and their parents strategies for effective emotion-regulation, self-control and problem-solving. Through SNAP, children, youth and parents have made positive gains by learning to make better choices â€œin the momentâ€ by learning to stop and think before they act and manage their emotions and impulses, and avoid conflict across multiple settings.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Long-term goals: â€¢	No involvement with criminal justice system â€¢	More productive citizens â€¢	Higher rate of high school graduates and youth in post-secondary education â€¢	Become more productive citizens  Short-term goals: â€¢	Increased emotion regulation using SNAP techniques â€¢	Decreased antisocial behaviour â€¢	Limited police contact â€¢	Increased social competence â€¢	Improved relationships with peers and adults â€¢	Increased sense of belonging and self-worth â€¢	Connection to positive  community activities and increased employment skills â€¢	Increased school engagement and success

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: My aim is to get youths involved in an organized program in an attempt to bring the energy, excitement and history of our people, their philosophy, moral values and principles. I hope to ignite the creative celebratory nature of the children, parents and the community to experience a higher level of understanding that promote healing, self-respect and creative possibilities in our daily lives. Together we will teach motivate, educate, inspire and unite everyone as a community through this art form.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Akwaba Was built upon a core curriculum in performing arts, but it also has an educational program through workshop, lecture and class-demonstration within African dance, music and mask history. The repertory is made up of dance, music, poetry and theatre performance derived from the social, spiritual, historical and political life of African society. This repertory is based on an extraordinary lively people culture. Akwaba performances are classical African folk arts with rustic charm of African traditional cultures.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: The Akwaba Method provide tremendous stress reducing benefits as well as the healthy release of physical and mental tensions. The drum and primal movements also encourage the expression of unspoken emotion, providing a safe and creative environment for its release. As a result participants or students are better equipped to respond spontaneously and creatively to their environment and to confront lifeâ€™s challenged with peace and clarity. The health release and emotional tension makes African dance and music a remedy for our fast-moving and high-pressure times.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: By teaching basic acting skills, having the young people work-up skits and sketches to create a show, which may include other skills such as music and singing, and then performing in long-term care facilities and retirement homes, we instill core values of respect for others and self, the necessity of self-discipline while working as a team, we help build self-confidence and resistance to peer pressure by presenting an alternative to self destructive and anti-social behaviours that can afflict vulnerable and impressionable young people.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Acting, especially acting in an ensemble, requires self-discipline and teamwork. It also requires self-confidence, and out program builds that without the participant realising that it is happening. We have seen participants who were extremely reluctant to be the centre of attention learn how empowering it can be to command a stage, with the support of other cast members, and the self-belief that we can teach. The first time a young person says one line and gets a laugh or a reaction, there is an immediate sense of enhanced self-confidence and belief in self.  Starting with small parts, the participants will grow into larger parts, with the help of the instructors and other participants. The latter will have gone through the same process, and many will become leaders and mentors. Much better to get a high by acting on stage, that to get a high by inhaling or injecting drugs.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Self-confidence Self respect Working with others Creativity Self-expression, better use of voice and speaking skills Respect for self and others, especially the elderly. Leadership and mentoring skills Better grades at school especially in presentations, English and Drama Resistance to peer pressure Alternative to drugs and alcohol Volunteerism (more experienced participants have exceeded the necessary 40 hours voluntary work by working as assistants and mentors at our summer camp)

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The Crew is a unique opportunity, an after school program offered to boys in grade 7 and 8. We create an environment for young boys where they have a sense of belonging and are able to realize there potential. The Crew provides a venue to discuss topics such as substance abuse, vandalism, conflict resolution, bullying, life goals, sex, community welfare and environmental sustainability, so that participants can make good educated decisions.  Providing awareness is essential for personal growth and direction.  A key aspect of the program is physical activity, which incorporates teamwork, communication and leadership. Furthermore, the program offers a healthy snack each week demonstrating healthy lifestyle choices and teaching the boys the importance of nutrition.   The Crewâ€™s focus and dedication to educate youth on important topics, to have them involved in physical activities and to stress the importance of nutrition and environmental sustainability offers a program like no other.  Our volunteer mentors serve as excellent role models and foster positive relationships in the community providing support and strengthening awareness. This dedication to provide a service for building awareness creates a platform for success for male youth in our community. The Crew is a perfect environment for young males to feel inspired and empowered to go fourth and take the right path. ?

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The Pearl Project is a new, grassroots initiative created to support and serve young people who graduate out of the foster care system or otherwise live on the fringes of society, marginalized by poverty, loss or other circumstances beyond their control.     For too long theyâ€™ve been told that when they turn 18 they are on their own. As a society, we cast them into independence with some modest financial benefits, but mostly they leave foster care or their group home with no backup plan, no community, no one looking out for them. Then we ask them to walk the high-wire to adulthood essentially on their own.  To succeed they need to know someone has their back; that theyâ€™re not alone; that their personal success matters to us all.  JF&CS founded the Pearl Project to help balance their practical needs for skills and information with their need for community, connections and long term commitment. As a Jewish community we want them to know they matter to us, that we have their backs. Using a combination of creative programming and community collaborations, it is our goal to reveal the precious pearl that is each of these young people - gems too long hidden away by their hard lives.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Building and sustaining meaningful connection and sense of community in partnership with other community agencies/groups. We will use Social Enterprise, Mentorship and other engagement vehicles to build and sustain these connections.

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The primary objective of this program is to develop the resilience of young people facing multiple, complex and intersecting issues.  The Studio is an inclusive, youth-driven drop-in centre for 13 to 21-year-olds that openly celebrates LGBTQ+ youth, and attracts a diverse population from across the GTA. The young people who find their way to The Studio are marginalized for various reasons: mental health and substance use; social issues; stigma and isolation associated with identifying as LGBTQ+; and/or coming from a racialized or low income background.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: The goal of this program is to build a stronger sense of community among different youth and provide opportunities for youth to engage more fully with trusted adults and peers.  This is grounded in the model we have developed for an inclusive, integrated, safe space, for all youth which also prioritizes the needs of LGBTTQ youth. Another key principle is the involvement of youth in every aspect of the program decision making providing them with opportunities to develop social, life and leadership skills.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: The outcomes we have identified include:  An increase in key resilience measures such as the presence of a positive adult relationship and supportive peers, A positive sense of identity Improved access to necessary resources both material resources and social services Improved sense of community reflected by improved social participation/engagement

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Children and youth in this low-income, high poverty, high crime, ethno-culturally diverse neighbourhood are at-risk for mental and emotional issues but some of these problems can be off-set by participating in a sports and recreation program like ours. We provide a safe place for inner city children and youth to hang out after school where they can play sports and get exercise, use the computers for recreation or schoolwork, arts and crafts, dance, music and a variety of other activities. We believe all children and youth should have access to recreational activities and we provide it free. We also provide healthy snacks and have a cooking program where kids can learn to make simple recipes.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Arts- based
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: To open their minds to see that they have many possibilities and opportunities. To be encouraged /inspired to take school seriously and go on to post secondary education. Develop mentoring and leadership ability and encourage older participants to volunteer and later work in our program. Increase mental and physical well-being and develop social and academic skills that increase chances of success in school and work.
properties.Outcomes1: 7 - Ontario youth achieve academic success
properties.Outcomes2: 1 - Ontario youth are physically healthy
properties.Outcomes3: 17 - Ontario youth are engaged in their communities

properties.Name_Program: We are a youth serving agency, so all of our programs and services are youth specific.
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: We are a community health agency serving the needs of youth in Toronto. We provide accessible and inclusive programs and services that promote healthy sexuality and informed decision-making. We believe in supporting the whole person. To do so, we offer primary, sexual and reproductive, and mental health services for youth. We conduct community based research to answer questions and identify assets, gaps and barriers to improve our services. And to give youth the skills and information they need to make informed choices about all aspects of their health, we provide customized programming, such as workshops, peer education, and ongoing sessions.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Clinical health services, mental health services, peer programming, health promotion, workshops
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: These vary across the agency as we have many programs and services for youth.

properties.Contact_Name: Janice Tsoi (Program Manager of Immigrant Youth Center in York Region); Connie Leung (PM of Community Services in Toronto)
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: academic, cultural, economic, and social integration in the local communities.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: CICS uses a welcoming and asset-building approach to provide immigrant youth a space for positive development and social integration. Our innovative programming is based on the Five Cs Model (i.e., competence, confidence, connection, character, caring/compassion) to prepare immigrant youth to contribute positively to their schools and families, and the community they live in. Targeting youth between the ages of 13 and 24, CICS provides one-on-one supportive counselling, orientation programs and a range of 5Cs building workshops and activities. Besides addressing their settlement needs, we aim to help them excel and succeed in Canada. Examples of service activities include needs and assets assessment, skills and knowledge building, mentorship, leadership training, career path building, positive identity building, and community engagement.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: â€¢ Youth play an active role in identifying their needs, goals and assets to develop their action plans. â€¢ Youth are able to access settlement and other youth services offered by CICSâ€™s Immigrant Youth Centre and Immigrant Resource Centre. â€¢ Youth are made aware of other youth services available in the community. â€¢ Youth indicate increased understanding of the self and knowledge of the Canadian system to access community resources that meet their needs. â€¢ Youth will acquire the confidence, connection, competence, character, and compassion they need to fully integrate in local communities.  â€¢ Youth obtain peer and professional support they need to cope with the challenges in their transition in life.
properties.Outcomes1: 20 - Ontario youth know about and easily navigate resources in their communities

properties.Name_Program: We offer numerous youth program; youth at risk, harm reduction programs, newcomer specific, employment, leadership development
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: The scope of our programs is quite broad. The overarching theme is building a healthy and inclusive community. We do this various levels of health and fitness programs, community based programs and government funded programs. Each program addresses key objectives but collectively feed the common thread of health and inclusiveness.  We use the pillars of Asset Development to guide our measurable outcomes and program design.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: As mentioned previously Asset Development is the over arching model. The more assets a youth/individual has the greater chance for "success". Depending on program there could be group work/team building and/or individual counselling. One of our greatest strengths is our ability to engage our community partners. As an example, our Employment and Newcomer office houses 20+ programs being delivered by 8 different agencies. Each agency plays an integral role in moving the youth/individual along the employment and/or settlement continuum; Wrap around affect.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: This is not easy to answer and would take a great deal of time to list all outcomes as there a numerous programs, each with its own set of outcomes.

properties.Program_Funder: Various funders.

properties.Name_Program: Youth Empowered to Thrive AFRICA -(YET AFRICA) a program at Africans In Partnership Against AIDS
properties.Contact_Name: Mary Ndungu - SUPPORT WORKER AT APAA(AFRICANS IN PARTNERSHIP AGAINST AIDS)
properties.OtherSpecified: Support services for youth infected and affected by HIV
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Support of youth in linguistically and cultural manner.Sexual health, well being and supports around dealing with HIV diagnosis and challenges that come with it.Education around safer sex practices for the infected and affected youth,use of art therapy , one on one peer support, support groups and other techniques to address issues of self esteem, self-stigma, and stigma and discrimination as a whole.Support youth around HIV disclosure and its impact on their health and well being.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: The program teaches them that HIV is not who they are â€“ it is just an infection they have. And that they are human beings with inner and unlimited strengths and potential. The aim of the Self Discovery intervention is to provide newly diagnosed young people with a range of practical skills including goal setting, effective communication and negotiation skills. use  of  self assessment , journaling,expressive arts therapy to enhance their emotional well being, and improve on treatment adherence and selfcare .use of  Role play, individual and group exercises too.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: we, have successful strategies for self growth, assessing self, deal with loss process, SMART Goals principles, implementing a action plan, use of mantraâ€™s and journaling, breaking the silence and HIV disclosure.  In the end the clients  exhibit increased self confidence; increased awareness of self and HIV; improved communication skills and self confidence to discuss their HIV status with family and friends; improved treatment adherence , improved health and are now more focused on other stuff/challenges  rather than on self.  eventually they are able to deal with their other challenges e.g. sexuality disclosing sexual orientation to friends and family etc .
properties.Outcomes1: 13 - Ontario youth experience social inclusion and value diversity
properties.Outcomes2: 2 - Ontario youth feel mentally healthy
properties.Program_Funder: AIDS BUREAU ontario ministry of health and long term care

properties.Name_Program: Youth Job Connection, JobStart, Career Focus, Boot Camp, Career Sampler, InSight-Youth Mentoring Partnership
properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: KEYS has been delivering youth employment programs for over 35 years in the Kingston and surrounding communities. We offer support to help youth make informed career and education decisions, gain employability skills through pre-employment training and on-the-job training. Our focus is on two groups of youth; youth at-risk and facing barriers to employment, and recent post-secondary grads who need support to transition into a professional work place setting related to their field of study. We want our youth to  combination of paid work placements, career coaching, mentorship, and information about postsecondary education and training opportunities in order to make informed decisions and gain labour market attachment. The underlying issues we address through our innovative programs are the foundational building blocks of helping people reach their full potential. At the same time we support economic development and community capacity building.
properties.Program_Practice_Model_Notes: We take a stenghts based assessment approach to our wotk with youth clients, focussing on assests and interests, skills development.  We prioritize service coordination and a strong belief system that people can and do change and want to reach thier potential.
properties.Program_Outcomes_Notes: Employment or enhanced employability Training completion or continued education
properties.Outcomes1: 7 - Ontario youth achieve academic success
properties.Outcomes2: 10 - Ontario youth have opportunities for meaningful employment opportunities
properties.Program_Funder: various levels of government

properties.Program_Issues_Addressed: Youth Job Link, launching in spring 2016, is designed to help youth, including students, aged 15 to 29, who do not face significant barriers to employment, but who could benefit from some extra help to plan their careers and transition to the labour market.   Youth Job Link will provide three categories of non-intensive employment services, each of which will be available year-round. They are:  Career exploration services to increase knowledge of career options and support career decision-making; Career management services to improve readiness for the labour market; and, Job search, readiness and matching assistance to connect youth with employers offering employment opportunities, including summer jobs.
